ARABIAN MAXIMS.

From work entitled Sketches of Persia.


The following admirable lines were in
scribed upon golden crown having five
sides, which was found IN the tomb of Moo
sherwan.


First stde.-"Consider the end before you
begin, and before you advance provide re-
treat.


Give not unnecessary pain to any man,
but study the happiness Of all.


Ground not your dignity upon your power
to hurt Others"
Second Side.--"Take counsel before you
commence any measure, and never trust its
execution to the inexperienced.
Sacrifice your property for your lite, and
your life for your religion.
Spend your time in establishing good
name, and if you desire fortune, learn con-
tentment.''


Third side-"Grieve not for that which
is brok en-, stolen, burnt or lost.
Never give orders in another mans house,
accustom yourself to eat your bread at your
own table.
Make not Yourself the captive of women" "
Fourth Side-" Take not wife from a
bad family, and seat not thyself with those
who have no shame.
! Keep thyself at a distance from those who
are incorrigiblc in bad habits. and hold no
intercourse with that man who is insenslble
| TO Kindness.
| Covet not the goods of others.


Be guarded with monarchs, for they are
like fire, which bazeth and deatroyeth.
| BE sensible to Your own value, estimate
justly the warth Of others: and war not with
those who are tar above thee in fortune" ;"


Fitth Side.-"Fear Kings, women and po-
cts.
! Be envious of no man, and avoid being out
of temper, or thy life will pass in misery.


Respect and protect the females OF thy
family.


Be not the slave of anger; and in thy con-
test always leave open the door OF concilia-
ton.


Never let your expenses exceed your in
come.


Plant young tree or you cannot expect
to cut down an old one.


Stretch your legs no farther than the size
of your carpet

ing up only the present number of these in
teresting extracts. After his splendid Sc
ries of successes, already detailed and upon
the triumph OF the anti. Bourbon members
of the directory, Buonaparte repaired to Par
is, and his situation and department there,
are thus described by his biographer -


"In the metropolis where all is welcome
that can vary the tedium of ordinary life. the
arrival of anv remarkable persons is spe- |
cies of holiday; but such an eminent charac-
ter as Buonapartc-the conqueror--the sage
the poltician--the undaunted bravcr of
every ditflculty--the inviaclhle victor in ev-
cry battle who had carried the banners of
the Republic from Genoa, till their approach
scared the Pontiff in Rome, and the Empe-
ror in Vienna, was no every day wonder
His youth, too, added to the marvel, and
still more the claim of general superiority
over the society in which he mingled, tho
consisting Of the most distinguished persons
in France, a superiority cloaket itself with
species Of reverse, which inferred, You
may look upon me, but you cannot penetrate
or see through me- Napolcon's general
manner in society, during this part OF his
life, has been described by an observer OF
Grst-ratc power; according to whom ne was
one for whom the admiration which could
not be refused to him, was always mingled
with portion of fear. He WAS different in
his manner from other men, and neither
pleased nor angry, kind nor severe, after the
common fashion of humanity. He appear
ed to live for the execution of his own plans.
and to consider others only in SO far as they
were connected with, and could advance or
oppose them. lie estimated his fellow NOR
tails no otherwise than as they could be use
| full to his views. and, with precision OF in
telligence which seemed intuitivc from its
rapiditv he penetrated the sentiments OF
those whom it was worth his while to study.
| 8uonaparte did not then possess the ordina-
ry tone Of light conversation in society; prob
ably his mind was too much ourthened or
too proud to stoop to adopt that mode OF
pleasing, and there was a Stiffness and re-
serve Of manner which was perhaps adopt
ed for the purpose Of keeping people at dis
tance. His looks had the same character.
When he thought himself closely observed,
he had the power OF discharging from his
countenance all expression, save that OF
vague and indefinite smile, and presenting
to the curious Investigator the fixed eyes and
rigid features ofa bust of marble.


When he talked with the purpose of
pleasing, Buonaparte often told anecdotes OF
his life in very pleasing manner; when 81
lent, he had something dsdaintul IN the ea-
preston of his face; disposed to be
quite at case, he was. in Madam dc Staels
opinion, rather vulgar. his natural tone OF
feeling seemed to be a sense OF internal SUI
perior,ty, and of secret contempt for the
world in which he lived, the men with whom
he acted. and even the very objects which
he pursued. His character and manners
were upon the whole, strongly calculated to


oF
and to excite perpetual interest even from
the very mystery which attached to him, as
we'll MS from the splcndor of his triumphs.
The supreme power was residing III the
Luxembourg ostensiby; but Paris was "a
ware that the means which had raised, and
which must support and extend that power.
were to be found in the humble mansion OF

ungallantly expresses it, tormented hH

ed French phrase, they stood in false po

a thinking it would be difficult to resist he

sire to look into him with considerate eyes,


and on one occasion put his abilities to tn


preof, by asking him rather abruptly, in tn
r middle Of brilliant party at Talleyrand's

the Huns, as had taken place in the days OF
At.ila, while the French Emperor was to
enact the second Theodrick."

"You are old Father William, the Young man


cred


The few locks that are left you are gray,
You are hale, Father William, hearty old man
Now tell me the reason pray"
SIN the days off my youth, Father William replied,
remembered that youth would f1y fast,
And abus'd not my health andmy vigor at first,
That never might need them at last.''
"you are old, Father William, the young man


cried,


And pleasure with you pass away;
And yet you lament not the days that are gone,
Now tell me the reason pray"
aIn the days ofmy YOUTH Father William replied,
remembered that youth could not last,
Thought on the future, whatever did,
That never might grieve for the past"
oYou are old, Father William, the young man


cried,


And life must be fastening away,
You are cheerful, and love to converse upon


DEATH


Now tell me the reason pray"
II am cheerful young man, Father William ra-


piled,


Let the cause thy attention engage:
In the days Of my youth remembered my God!
And He hath not forgotten my age"

uncle would S4 glad 10 offer home to in

full articles.headline: ARABIAN MAXIMS.
full articles.article:
This world is field soved for another
life.


The most incurahle disease is ignorance.


All secrets which pass beyond two, make
themselves known.


Prefer the day of to-day to that OF to-mor-
row.


He who is Of unknown arigini discovered
by his works.


Where the heart is inclined, there also
will the feet turn.


Love is shown by kind actions, and not by
fair speeches.


1t IS better to go round the stream than
drown in crossing.


We must take pains, if we expect to get
any thing. =,


Death is nearer to US than the e!2-lld to
the eye.


The little which suffices, is better than
the much which disturbs us.


The best of mans possessions is sincere
friend.


The eulogium made on the absent, serves
to incline our hearts TO the present.
The best Of riches is contentmcnt the
| worst Of poverty, low spirits.
Who lights a fire that others may warm
themselves. :.
| Labor for this life as if thou vert TO ilvt
forever; and for the other, as Ii thou wcrt t'
| die to morrow,


! Desire not either the wise man or the toe
for thine enemy; but guard thyselt equally
from the cunning OF the wise man, ana th'
ignorance Of the fool


The man who contents himself to-day
with that which he has. will content himsel
to- morrow with that which he may nave
| There is no tomorrow which cannot d
converted into to-day.
| He will never save himself who does no
labor for his soul before the day OF ITS dc
struction.

From work entitled Sketches of Persia.


The following admirable lines were in
scribed upon golden crown having five
sides, which was found IN the tomb of Moo
sherwan.


First stde.-"Consider the end before you
begin, and before you advance provide re-
treat.


Give not unnecessary pain to any man,
but study the happiness Of all.


Ground not your dignity upon your power
to hurt Others"
Second Side.--"Take counsel before you
commence any measure, and never trust its
execution to the inexperienced.
Sacrifice your property for your lite, and
your life for your religion.
Spend your time in establishing good
name, and if you desire fortune, learn con-
tentment.''


Third side-"Grieve not for that which
is brok en-, stolen, burnt or lost.
Never give orders in another mans house,
accustom yourself to eat your bread at your
own table.
Make not Yourself the captive of women" "
Fourth Side-" Take not wife from a
bad family, and seat not thyself with those
who have no shame.
! Keep thyself at a distance from those who
are incorrigiblc in bad habits. and hold no
intercourse with that man who is insenslble
| TO Kindness.
| Covet not the goods of others.


Be guarded with monarchs, for they are
like fire, which bazeth and deatroyeth.
| BE sensible to Your own value, estimate
justly the warth Of others: and war not with
those who are tar above thee in fortune" ;"


Fitth Side.-"Fear Kings, women and po-
cts.
! Be envious of no man, and avoid being out
of temper, or thy life will pass in misery.


Respect and protect the females OF thy
family.


Be not the slave of anger; and in thy con-
test always leave open the door OF concilia-
ton.


Never let your expenses exceed your in
come.


Plant young tree or you cannot expect
to cut down an old one.


Stretch your legs no farther than the size
of your carpet

From the Albany Argus.
BROTHER JONArHAN's THOUGHTS ON
VIEWING THE FALLS OF NIAGARA
1wonder how long ye'yc been roarin'
At this tremendous rate!
l wonder if all we've been ponrn'
Could be cypher'd on slate!
1wonder how such thun,ern' sounded
When all New-York was woods!
'Spose likely some Indians have been drownded.
When rains have raised your Hoods!
wontlcr'f wild stags and butfaloes
Hay'nt stood where now stand,
Well, 'spose (bcins scared at first) they'd stub.


bed their toes
Iwonder where they'd land
Iwonder If that rainbow has been shinln'
Since sunrise at creation
And this waterfall been undermining,
With constant spatteratlon,
That Moses never mentioned We, I've wonder'd,
While other things describin';
Ny conscicncel how ye must have foam'd and


thunder'd,


When the deluge was subsidin'!
my thoughts are strange" magnificent and


deep,


"When look down to thee
OH what glorious place for washing sheep
Niagara would be!
And o. what tremendous water power
Is wasted DER its edge
One man might furnish all the world with flour,
With single privilege!
Iwondcr how many times the lakes have all
Been empticd over here
Why Clinton didn't feed the Grand Canal
Up here, think is queer
"The thoughts are very strange which now crowd


my brain,


While look up to thee''-
Such thoughts never expect to have again,
To all eternity

tall was 10Y in Mrs. Fletcher's dwell
ing. My dear mother' said Evereil, sit is
now quite time to look out Tor father and
Hope Leslie. have turned the hour glass
three times since dinner, and counted all the
sands think. Let us all go on the front por-
tico where we can catch the first glimpse
of them, as they come past the elm trees
Here, Oneco,' he continued, as he saw as
sent in his mothers smile, "hclp me out
with mothers rocking chair-rataer rough
rocking, he added, as he adjusted the rock-
ers lcng hwisc with the logs that served Tor
the floorlng--"Eut mother wont mind tri1es
Just now. All blessed babe, brother" he
continued, taking in his arms the beautiful
infant-"you Shall come too, even though
you cheat me out of my birthright, and get
the first embrace from father" Thus say
ing, he placed the laughing infant in his 60
cart, beside his mother. He then aided his
little sisters in the arrangement of the play
things they had brought forth to welcome
and astonish Hope; and finally he made an
elevated position for Faith Leslie, where
she might, he said, as she ought, catch the
first glimpse of her sister.


"Thank you, Everell, said the little girl,
as she mounted her pinnacle, "if YOU knew
Hope Leslie, yon would want to see her first
! too-every body loves Hope. We shall al
ways have pleasant times when Hope gets
| here"


| 1t was one of the most beautiful alter
moons at the close of the month OF May
The tagging spring had at last come forth
in all her power; her "work of glAdness
was finished, and forests, fields and meadows
were bright with renovated life. The tnll
Connecticut swept triumphantly on, as Il
still exultng in its release from its fctters o
winter. Every gushing riil had the spring.
note of joy, the meadows were, Tor the hrs
time, enriched with patches OF English grain
which the new settlers had sown, scantiiy
by way of experiment, prudently occupyin.
the greatest portion Of the rich mould, witt
the native Indian corn. This product OF oul
soil is beautiful in all its progress, from th'
moment when, as it now studded the mea
dow with hilocks, shooting its bright point
ed spear from its mother earth. to It's matu
rity, when the long golden ear bursts IRON
the rnstling leaf.


The grounds about Mrs. Fletcher's hous
had been prepared with the neatness Q
English taxte; and rich bed OF clover tina
oyersprcad the lawn Immediately before TIL
portice, already rewarded the industry
the cultivators. Over this delicate carpe
the domestic fowls, the first civilized inhae
itants of the ceunAry, Of their tribe, were no

Plough deep, and you will reap abund-
ance of corn.


A secret between two is Gods secret; a
secret between three is every body's.


The best work a mother can do is to
take care of her children.


Nothing great can be effected without
trouble and labor.

THO Use WlUlStcTS Ahu WI ohiPRSAS Va "~sNA~S
we're on the wing, filling the air with melody
while like diligent little housewives they
forest and field for materials tor
their ousekeeping.


A mother, encircled by healthful sporting
is always beautiful spectacle-a
spectacle that appeals to nature in every hu-
man breast. Mrs. Fletcher, in obedience to
matrimonial duty, or, it may be, from some
lingering female vanity, had on this occasion
attired herself with extraordinary care
What woman does not wish to look hand
some.-in the eyes of her husband.


"Mother," said Everell, putting aside the
exquisitely fine lace that shaded her cheeks
II do not believe you looked more beautiful
than you do to-day, when, as have hearo:
they called you the rose OF the wilderness
Our little Mary's cheek is as round and as
bright as peach, but it is not so handsome
as yours, mother. Your heart has sent TINS
color here" he continued, kissing her ten.
derly--"it seems to have come forth to tell
US that our father is near"


aIt would shame me, Everell, replied his
mother, embracing him with feeling thae
the proudest lrawing-room belle might have
envied, to take such hattery from any liPs.
but thine"


"Oh do not call it flattery, mother-look,
Marawisca-for heavens sake cheer up
look, would you know mether's eye! Just
turn it. mother. one minute from that road
and herpale cheek too-with this rich ssl-
or on it,"


ALAS alas" replied Magawsca, glancine
her ewes at Mrs. Fletcher, and then as II
heart struck Withdrawing them, show soon
does the flush of the setting sun fade from
the evening cloud"


"Oh Magawisca," said Everell impati-





is too sweet for bird of ill-omen. l shall
begin to think as Jennet sa, Though Jen.
net is no text t-book for mel shall begin
10 think old Nelema has really bewltched
you" =,
"You call me bird of ill-omen," replied
Mapawisca, half proud, half sorrowful, sand
you call the owl bird OF ill-omen, but we
| hold him sacred-he is our sentinel, and
when danger is nigh, he cries, awake a.
wake!"


.Magawisca, you are positively unkind---
Jere emah's lamentations on holiday would
not be more out of time than your croakinE
is now-the very skies, earth, air, seems to
partake our Joy at fathers return, and you
only make discord. Do you think if your
father was near would not share your joy!''


Tears fell fast from Magawisca's eyes,
but she made no reply, and MRS. Fletcher
observing and comPasslonating her EMOTION
and thinking it probably arose from COM
pairing her orphan state to that of the mer-
~ children about her, called her and said,
"Magawisca, you are neither stranger
nor a servant, will you not share our joyt
Do you not love usf''


love you,'' she exclaimed, clasping her
hands, .,love you. ! would give my life tor
you"


awe do not ask your life, my good girl"
repied Mrs. Fletcher, kindly smiling on
her "but a light heart and cheerful look,
A sad countenance doth not become this joy
full hour. Go and help Oneco-he is quite
out of breath blowing those soap bubbles tor
the children"


Oneca smiled, and shook his head, and
continued to send off one after another OF the
prismatic globes, and AS they rose and hoat-
ed OH the air and frightened with the many
colored ray, the little girls clapped their
hands, and the little baby stretched his 70
grasp the brilliant vapor.


"Oht" said Magawisca, impetuously, CO.
vering her eyes, Il do not like to see any
thing so beautiful, pass SO quickly away"
Scarcely had she uttered these words,
when suddenly, as if the earth had opened
on them, three Indian warriors darted from
the forest, and pealed on the air their horri-
BILE wells.


My father! my tasher!" burst from the
lips of Magawisca and Oneco.
! Faith Leslie sprang towards the Indian
boy, and clung fast to him-and the children
!. clustered about their mother-she instinct
, lively caught her infant and held it close
within her arms, as if their Intellectual shell
. ter were rampant.


Maqawisca uttered a cry of agony, and
sprneihg forward with her arms upllfteds
, as ii deprecating his approach. she sunk
I down az her fathers feet, and caspins her
: Hands, "saye them-saye them," she crieds
3 "the mother-the childTen-oh they are all


good--take vengeance on your eneniles-out
: spare--spare our friends--our benefactors--
: bleed when they are struck-oh command
i them 10 standi" she screamed, looking TO
. the companions of her father, who uncheck-
ed by her cries, were pressing on to their
f Mononotto was silent and motionless, his
Il eve glanced wildly from Magawsca to One
: CO. Magawisca replied to the glance Of tire
4 ives. they have sheltered us-save them
save them-oh it will be too late,' she
! cried, springing IRON her father, whose ST.
= lrnce and fixedness showed that it his better
i nature rebelled against the work OF reveng'
r there was no reenting OF purpose. Maga
9 wisca darted before the Indian who was ad
j. vancing towards Mrs. Fletcher with an up

full articles.headline: LIFE. oF NAPOLEON.
full articles.article:
ing up only the present number of these in
teresting extracts. After his splendid Sc
ries of successes, already detailed and upon
the triumph OF the anti. Bourbon members
of the directory, Buonaparte repaired to Par
is, and his situation and department there,
are thus described by his biographer -


"In the metropolis where all is welcome
that can vary the tedium of ordinary life. the
arrival of anv remarkable persons is spe- |
cies of holiday; but such an eminent charac-
ter as Buonapartc-the conqueror--the sage
the poltician--the undaunted bravcr of
every ditflculty--the inviaclhle victor in ev-
cry battle who had carried the banners of
the Republic from Genoa, till their approach
scared the Pontiff in Rome, and the Empe-
ror in Vienna, was no every day wonder
His youth, too, added to the marvel, and
still more the claim of general superiority
over the society in which he mingled, tho
consisting Of the most distinguished persons
in France, a superiority cloaket itself with
species Of reverse, which inferred, You
may look upon me, but you cannot penetrate
or see through me- Napolcon's general
manner in society, during this part OF his
life, has been described by an observer OF
Grst-ratc power; according to whom ne was
one for whom the admiration which could
not be refused to him, was always mingled
with portion of fear. He WAS different in
his manner from other men, and neither
pleased nor angry, kind nor severe, after the
common fashion of humanity. He appear
ed to live for the execution of his own plans.
and to consider others only in SO far as they
were connected with, and could advance or
oppose them. lie estimated his fellow NOR
tails no otherwise than as they could be use
| full to his views. and, with precision OF in
telligence which seemed intuitivc from its
rapiditv he penetrated the sentiments OF
those whom it was worth his while to study.
| 8uonaparte did not then possess the ordina-
ry tone Of light conversation in society; prob
ably his mind was too much ourthened or
too proud to stoop to adopt that mode OF
pleasing, and there was a Stiffness and re-
serve Of manner which was perhaps adopt
ed for the purpose Of keeping people at dis
tance. His looks had the same character.
When he thought himself closely observed,
he had the power OF discharging from his
countenance all expression, save that OF
vague and indefinite smile, and presenting
to the curious Investigator the fixed eyes and
rigid features ofa bust of marble.


When he talked with the purpose of
pleasing, Buonaparte often told anecdotes OF
his life in very pleasing manner; when 81
lent, he had something dsdaintul IN the ea-
preston of his face; disposed to be
quite at case, he was. in Madam dc Staels
opinion, rather vulgar. his natural tone OF
feeling seemed to be a sense OF internal SUI
perior,ty, and of secret contempt for the
world in which he lived, the men with whom
he acted. and even the very objects which
he pursued. His character and manners
were upon the whole, strongly calculated to


oF
and to excite perpetual interest even from
the very mystery which attached to him, as
we'll MS from the splcndor of his triumphs.
The supreme power was residing III the
Luxembourg ostensiby; but Paris was "a
ware that the means which had raised, and
which must support and extend that power.
were to be found in the humble mansion OF
1.-THE ewlv-christencG Rue des Victories.


Some Of tho features are perhaps rashly
designed, as being drawn recentibus odlis.-
The disagreement between Buonaparte and
Madame de Stac, from whom we have
briefly described them, is we'll known. 1t
originated about this time, when, as first
, rate woman of talent, she was naturally de-
, sirous to attract the notice of the Victor OF
Vctors. They appeared to have misunder-
, stood each ether; for the lady who ought
certainly to know best, has informed US,
"that far from feeling her fear OF buona-
i, parte removed by repeated meetings, II
seemed to increase, and his best exertions to
please, could not overcome her invlnciole
aversion for what she found in his charac-
. ter" His ironical contempt of excellence
! of every kind, operated like the sword IN ro-
nance, which froze while it wounded Buo-
paparte seems never to have suspected the
secret and mysterious terror with which he
impressed the ingenious author of Corinnc


on the contrary, Las Cases tells US that sht
$ combined all her efforts, and all her means
to make an impression on the general. She
, wrote him when distant, and as the Count


ungallantly expresses it, tormented hH


when present. In truth, to use an establish


ed French phrase, they stood in false po
stion with respect to each other.


Madame de Stael might be pardoned fo
a thinking it would be difficult to resist he


wit and her talent, when exerted with thu
n purpose of pleasing; but Buonaparte wa


disposed to repcl. rather than encourage th
L advances of one whose views was SO shrewl


and her observation so keen, while her Sc,
: permitted her TO push her inquiries farthe


than one man might have dared to do in con
j, versing with another. She certainly did de


sire to look into him with considerate eyes,


and on one occasion put his abilities to tn


preof, by asking him rather abruptly, in tn
r middle Of brilliant party at Talleyrand's


Whom he esteemed the greatest woman i
